purpose_overview.goal: Support fat loss, preserve/build lean muscle mass, and enhance recovery by prioritizing a higher proportion of daily calories from protein.
purpose_overview.approach: Increase protein intake significantly above the standard RDA (0.8 g/kg/day) into the 1.6–2.4 g/kg/day range, while balancing carbohydrates and fats according to individual goals.
best_for: Those with high satiety needs or prone to overeating
purpose_overview.why_it_works: Protein has the highest thermic effect (20–30% of calories burned during digestion), strongly supports satiety, and is essential for muscle protein synthesis.

caloric_strategy.fat_loss: 15–25% below TDEE. Protein intake protects lean mass.
caloric_strategy.muscle_gain: 10–15% surplus with elevated protein to maximize MPS.
caloric_strategy.body_recomposition: Maintenance calories + higher protein intake (2.0–2.4 g/kg/day) can favor fat loss and muscle gain simultaneously.

macronutrient_breakdown.protein: 1.6–2.4 g/kg/day (up to 3.0 g/kg/day in aggressive cuts).
macronutrient_breakdown.fiber: 25–35 g/day from fruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains.

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: Spread evenly — 0.4–0.55 g/kg per meal across 3–6 meals.
meal_timing_distribution.post_workout: 20–40 g high-quality protein within 2 hours, ideally with carbs.
meal_timing_distribution.pre_sleep: 30–40 g slow-digesting protein (e.g., casein, Greek yogurt).
meal_timing_distribution.hydration: 35–45 ml/kg/day; increased protein requires adequate fluid intake.

supplements_optional: Whey/Casein Protein – Convenient to hit daily protein targets.
Creatine Monohydrate (3–5 g/day) – Enhances strength, lean mass, and recovery.
Collagen + Vitamin C – Supports joint and connective tissue health.
BCAAs/EAAs – Useful if training fasted, otherwise unnecessary with sufficient protein intake.
Omega-3s – Supports inflammation control and recovery.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – Adjust calories if progress stalls for >2 weeks.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_performance: Weekly – Ensure protein + carbs support training.

advantages: Preserves and builds muscle mass in both surplus and deficit.
Reduces hunger and improves diet adherence.
Supports metabolic rate via thermic effect of food (TEF).
Safe and effective for athletes and general population.
May improve body composition in recomposition phases.
limitations: Requires planning to distribute protein across meals.
High intake may be difficult for some without supplementation.
Social/cultural eating patterns may emphasize carbs/fats over protein.
Misconception of kidney strain – safe in healthy individuals, caution with kidney disease.
scientific_references: Morton RW et al. (2018). Effect of protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength. Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376–384.
